author: Andree Withey
title: Drunken Brisbane man forces ex-girlfriend into head-on smash causing serious injury, court told - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Map: Brisbane 4000 
A Brisbane man deliberately grabbed the steering wheel of his ex-girlfriend's car and tried to strangle her, causing her to crash head-on into a ute and leaving her seriously injured, a court has heard. 
Douglas Heath Deacon, 23, faced Brisbane Magistrates Court this morning on 13 charges, including dangerous interference of a car causing grievous bodily harm, domestic violence, torture, strangulation and wilful damage. 
Deacon's ex-girlfriend remains in hospital with serious injuries as a result of the car crash. 
Magistrate Anne Thacker read the police report on the incident aloud to the court. 
She was scathing in her assessment of Deacon's behaviour. 
According to police, Deacon was extremely drunk when he took control of the car, causing it to crash into the ute on Appleby Road, Stafford, just before half past eight last Sunday night. Female doctor and paramedic 'also attacked' 
Police said Deacon also attacked a female doctor who stopped to help at the roadside and was violent towards an off-duty paramedic who tried to help. 
"I don't need to be told by anybody that when the defendant is intoxicated he becomes extremely violent in context of the charges he's facing," Magistrate Thacker said. 
She told Deacon he was too dangerous to be released on bail. 
"There is too much evidence that you are an unacceptable risk of reoffending," she said. 
"They're all very serious allegations against you. 
"For the safety — not just of the victim but also for other road users and members of community — you've been refused bail." 
Deacon was remanded in custody to appear in the Brisbane Magistrates Court again on March 20. 
Police are still trying to speak to the doctor involved and have appealed for her to contact them. 
They also want to hear from anyone who has information about the incident last Sunday, especially if they have dash-cam footage of what took place.
